choices.text: Residual from barrel of gun
Gutter fracture of skull

questions.text: What is bullet wipe? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Residual from barrel of gun

 

Explanation:

 

A "bullet wipe" is a gray or black ring around an entrance bullet hole. The ring is formed by bullet lubricant, byproducts of propellant, traces of bullet metal, and residue in the gun barrel from previous use. It is caused due to residue from barrel of the gun.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Blackening: It occurs due to combustion (smoke) produced by burning of gun powder when a firearm is fired.

 

Option C) Gutter fracture of skull: It occurs due to a bullet passing adjacent to the skull

 

Option D) Tattooing: It occurs due to unburnt gun powder particles which gets deposited around the firearm wound.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bullet Wipe (Grease/Dirt Collar)

 

• Black/gray ring around gunshot wound.

• Composition includes bullet lubrication, paraffin, lead, barrel debris, and gun oil.

• Wider side of the ring indicates the direction of fire.

• More noticeable in shots from freshly oiled weapons.

• It  is dark in the center, fading towards the periphery.

• Prominent in clothing, termed as ‘bullet wipe.’

• It serve as proof of an entry wound in forensic analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is “ boot shape heart “

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital syphilis

 

Explanation:

 

Kassowitz's rule pertains to congenital syphilis. According to this rule, if a woman with untreated syphilis has multiple pregnancies, the likelihood of congenital syphilis affecting the fetus in later pregnancies decreases. This phenomenon is observed as a result of the immune system's adaptive response and potential changes in the transmission dynamics of the infection over successive pregnancies. Therefore, the rule suggests that with each subsequent pregnancy, the outcome for the fetus improves if the infection remains untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary syphilis: Primary syphilis involves the initial chancre or ulcer at the site of infection and is not related to Kassowitz's rule, which specifically addresses outcomes in congenital syphilis.

 

Option C. Secondary syphilis: Secondary syphilis is characterized by systemic manifestations such as skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions and is not related to Kassowitz's rule.

 

Option D. Latent syphilis: Latent syphilis refers to a stage where no symptoms are present but the infection is still systemic. Kassowitz's rule is not associated with latent syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kassowitz rule states that the likelihood of congenital syphilis infection decreases with each successive pregnancy in a woman with untreated syphilis.

 

Ref: Page no 343, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that typically requires regular monitoring of anticoagulant effect via activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).
  • Enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin), Fondaparinux (a synthetic pentasaccharide), and Dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor) generally do not require regular monitoring in most patients, although there may be specific clinical situations where monitoring is needed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chikungunya

 

The given history of fever and joint pain along with centrofacial hyperpigmentation shown in the image suggests a diagnosis of Chikungunya. Hyperpigmentation associated with Chikungunya fever is macular and most commonly affects the nose and cheeks.

 

  • Chik sign: Nose pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign. It appears as the fever subsides and persists for about 3–6 months.
  • The hyperpigmentation mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if the clinical history is not taken properly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dengue: Incorrect. Dengue fever does not typically present with centrofacial hyperpigmentation.

 

Option C. Melasma: Incorrect. Melasma presents as hyperpigmented patches but is unrelated to fever and joint pain.

 

Option D. Fixed drug eruption (FDE): Incorrect. FDE is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction characterized by well-defined, hyperpigmented plaques that occur at the same location on re-exposure to the drug. These lesions are usually associated with NSAIDs but present differently, often as brown hyperpigmented plaques following vesiculobullous lesions.

 

Additional Note on FDE:

 

  • FDE Characteristics: Typically occurs on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, or oral mucosa. Presents 30 min to 8 hours after drug exposure, with a burning sensation and reappearance at the same site.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with fever and joint pain developing centrofacial hyperpigmentation, consider Chikungunya fever, particularly with the presence of Chik sign on the nose and cheeks. Proper history is crucial to avoid misdiagnosis, such as mistaking the presentation for melasma.

choices.text: Hydralazine - heart failure
Atenolol - hemolytic anemia
Aliskiren - hypokalemia

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Verapamil – constipation


The correct match regarding the drug and its adverse effect (read carefully, they have not asked the indication) is verapamil causes constipation.

 

Verapamil is a Non DHP calcium channel blocker. It can cause constipation as its side effect.


Other Options:


Option A. Hydralazine is a vasodilator which can cause drug-induced lupus. It does not cause heart failure as an adverse effect, rather It is used in treatment of heart failure.


Option B. Atenolol is a cardio selective beta blocker. Bradycardia can be seen as a side effect, not hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia is a side effect of methyl dopa.


Option C. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. The side effect of aliskiren is hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is associated with constipation as a common adverse effect. Other drugs and their incorrect matches in this context include hydralazine (which can cause drug-induced lupus), atenolol (which does not cause hemolytic anemia), and aliskiren (which can cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia).

choices.text: Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen
Radial artery is the preferred site

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ICU. While taking a blood sample for ABG, which of the following steps would you not do? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

 

Explanation:

 

Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood: Traditionally, to prevent blood from clotting inside the syringe when obtaining an ABG, a small amount of heparin was added to the syringe. However, in contemporary practice, syringes used for ABG are pre-heparinized, which means they already contain a coating of dry heparin that will mix with the blood sample and prevent clotting. Adding additional heparin to such a syringe is unnecessary and can dilute the sample, potentially altering the results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder: This statement is accurate. A patient can have a mixed acid-base disorder where two primary disorders (e.g., metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis) coexist and "cancel" each other out, leading to a seemingly "normal" pH. However, when the components of the arterial blood gas (ABG) like PaCO2 and HCO3- are evaluated, abnormalities can be detected.

 

Option C. If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen: The modified Allen's test is a simple way to evaluate the collateral blood flow to the hand via the ulnar artery. Before taking a sample or placing an arterial line in the radial artery, it's a recommended step to ensure that if the radial artery becomes occluded, the hand will still receive adequate blood flow. If the test is negative (indicative of inadequate collateral flow), it's safer to choose an alternate site for arterial puncture.

 

Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site: The radial artery is commonly chosen for ABG sampling and arterial line placement due to its accessibility, the presence of collateral blood flow (via the ulnar artery), and its relatively superficial location which makes puncture technically easier. Furthermore, complications like hematoma or injury are less problematic at this location when compared to other potential sites, such as the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Adding extra heparin to pre-heparinized ABG syringes is unnecessary and can alter the blood sample.

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He has chest trauma, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. The patient is conscious but only able to speak in short phrases. On examination, there is hyperresonance on the affected side of the chest. What should be your next immediate step in managing this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

choices.text: Intra-abdominal infections

questions.text: Antimicrobial combinations are used in all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gonorrhea

 

Drug of choice for treatment of gonorrhea is single dose ceftriaxone therapy. It does not require combination therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. For Management of Tuberculosis, a combination of drugs consisting of Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol are used. In cases like MDR or XDR TB, other drugs like Bedaquiline, Levofloxacin, Ethionamide etc. are used in various combinations and in the form of different regimens.

 

Option C. Intraabdominal infections are generally polymicrobial in nature consisting of both aerobic and anaerobic microorganisms. Combination therapy with metronidazole and other agents like ciprofloxacin, cefepime, etc. are used as empirical agents to treat them.

 

Option D. Malaria: In case of Plasmodium vivax infection, Chloroquine is used for 3 days + Primaquine is added for 14 days. For P. Falciparum infection, combination therapy consisting of ACT-SP (Artesunate + Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine) are used along with a single dose of Primaquine on Day 2. For P. Falciparum infection in the north eastern states, ACT-AL (Artemether + Lumefantrine) is used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antimicrobial combination therapy is not used for the treatment of gonorrhea, which is typically managed with single-dose ceftriaxone therapy. In contrast, tuberculosis, intra-abdominal infections, and malaria require combination therapy to effectively manage the infections and prevent resistance.

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides? (AIIMS Nov 2018
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative feedback

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies changes and does not stabilize blood pressure.

 

Option C. Both negative and positive feedback: Incorrect. Baroreceptors primarily provide negative feedback to regulate blood pressure.

 

Option D. Feedforward control: Incorrect. Feedforward control anticipates changes and adjusts accordingly, but baroreceptors respond to changes rather than anticipating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback to help maintain blood pressure within normal limits by triggering responses that counteract increases in blood pressure.

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.text: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

 

Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.

 

Class I major histocompatibility complex are expressed on all nucleated cells

 

Class III major histocompatibility complex are some components of the complement system (C2 and C4) coded on HLA complex but are not associated with HLA expression and are not used in antigen identification.

 

 

MHC antigens present on the cell surface help the macrophage in its function of bacterial antigen recognition i.e., they help to identify self from foreign, and accordingly present the foreign antigen to T cells (CD4+ or CD8+) or to B cells.

 

MHC I are located on a portion of chromosome 6p of all nucleated cells of the body and platelets. These genes occupy four regions or loci—A, B, C and D, on the short (p) arm of chromosome 6 and exhibit marked variation in allelic genes at each locus. Therefore, the product of HLA antigens is highly polymorphic.

 

The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6.

 

Role of MHC/ HLA typing include:

 

  1. Organ Transplantation
  2. Regulation of immune system
  3. Association of diseases with HLA. An increasing number of diseases have been found to have association with some specific histocompatibility antigens. Ex:
  4. Inflammatory disorders e.g., ankylosing spondylitis
  5. Autoimmune disorders e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, insulin dependent diabetes mellitus.
  6. Inherited disorders of metabolism e.g., idiopathic haemochromatosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NK cells: While natural killer (NK) cells play a role in immune responses, they do not express MHC class II molecules.

 

Option B. All nucleated cells: This describes MHC Class I expression, not MHC Class II.

 

Option D. Platelets: Although platelets are derived from nucleated cells, they do not express MHC Class II molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC Class II molecules are primarily expressed on antigen presenting cells (B cells, dendritic cells, and mononuclear phagocytes), which are essential for antigen presentation to T-helper cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented to the casualty with Hb - 5.4 g/dL, urea-86 mg/dL, creatinine- 6 mg/dL, calcium - 12 mg/dL, potassium - 4.4 mEq/L. Bone marrow aspiration shows > 60% of plasma cells. What is the next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone + Fluids

 

Features are suggestive of Multiple myeloma presenting with Mild Hypercalcemia with no pulmonary edema. Hence, treatment with steroids and IV fluids are recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis is recommended if Hyperkalemia, Pulmonary edema, refractory acidosis, and Uremia.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone + lenalidomide is recommended in definitive therapy for MM along with bortezomib +/- Daratumumab (Anti CD38).

 

Option D. Bone marrow transplant is considered upfront in high-risk disease as definitive therapy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Immediate management of a newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patient presenting with anemia, renal failure, and hypercalcemia should prioritize rapid medical intervention to stabilize the patient. This includes hydration and the use of steroids to reduce plasma cell proliferation and calcium levels. Subsequent treatments will be based on the patient’s response and overall treatment strategy.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Plasma cell dyscrasia/Chap 111

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Papillary dermis

 

Explanation:

 

The papillary dermis is the uppermost layer of the dermis, lying directly beneath the epidermis. It is named so because of its projections called dermal papillae that interlock with the rete ridges of the epidermis.

 

These dermal papillae increase the surface area between the epidermis and dermis, allowing for better nutrient exchange and anchoring. Meissner corpuscles, also known as tactile corpuscles, are located in the papillary dermis, especially in areas sensitive to light touch, such as the fingertips and lips. They are oval-shaped mechanoreceptors that are sensitive to fine touch and low-frequency vibration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is the deeper and thicker layer of the dermis, located beneath the papillary dermis. It comprises mainly of dense irregular connective tissue containing collagen and elastin fibers. While it contains other structures like sweat glands, hair follicles, and blood vessels, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.

 

Option C. Basal epidermis: The basal epidermis, or stratum basale, is the innermost layer of the epidermis. It consists of a single layer of columnar or cuboidal keratinocytes. These cells are continuously dividing and pushing older cells upwards towards the skin surface. The basal layer also contains melanocytes, which produce the pigment melanin, and Merkel cells, another type of tactile mechanoreceptor. However, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.

 

Option D. Stratum lucidum: The stratum lucidum is a thin, clear layer of the epidermis, typically found only in areas of thick skin such as the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It lies between the stratum corneum (outermost layer) and the stratum granulosum. The stratum lucidum is made up of dead, flat keratinocytes that have a translucent appearance. Meissner corpuscles are not located in this epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanocyte are found in Stratum basale
  • Merkel cell found in stratum basale
  • Meissner corpuscles found in papillary dermis
  • Keratohyaline granules are found in stratum granulosum
  • Keratin is found in Stratum corneum & lucidum
     

 

Meissner corpuscles are found in papillary dermis, are enriched in the fingers and toes, and have an unmyelinated nerve terminal that is surrounded by Schwann cells.

choices.text: Mesangial cell contraction increases Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure.
Efferent arteriolar constriction decreases renal blood flow (RBF).
Mild constriction of the efferent arteriole decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
Mesangial cell contraction increases glomerular hydrostatic pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Efferent arteriolar constriction decreases renal blood flow (RBF).


This statement is correct. Constriction of the efferent arteriole increases the resistance to the outflow of blood from the glomerular capillaries. This increased resistance leads to a decrease in renal blood flow. Although the increased resistance may temporarily elevate the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, the overall blood flow through the kidneys decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesangial cell contraction increases Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure - Incorrect. Mesangial cell contraction does not affect Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure. Instead, it reduces the surface area available for filtration, impacting the glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and ultimately decreasing filtration efficiency.

 

Option C. Mild constriction of the efferent arteriole decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR) - Incorrect. Mild constriction of the efferent arteriole actually increases GFR because it raises the glomerular hydrostatic pressure. Only severe constriction would result in a decrease in GFR due to an increase in colloid osmotic pressure.

 

Option D. Mesangial cell contraction increases glomerular hydrostatic pressure - Incorrect. When mesangial cells contract, they cause blood flow to be diverted away from certain capillary loops, decreasing glomerular hydrostatic pressure rather than increasing it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Efferent arteriolar constriction decreases renal blood flow but can transiently increase glomerular filtration rate until severe resistance reduces GFR.

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tasimelteon

 

Tasimelteon and Ramelteon are melatonin agonists. Tasimelteon is used for the treatment of insomnia in blind persons, whereas Ramelteon is used for the treatment of jet lag and also used for sleep induction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latanoprostene: Is not relevant to the treatment of insomnia. It is a medication used to reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

 

Option B. Zerviate: Is an antihistamine eye drop used for the treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis, not for insomnia.

 

Option D. Ramelteon: Is also a melatonin receptor agonist used for the treatment of insomnia, specifically for difficulties with sleep onset. It is not specifically indicated for Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder in blind individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tasimelteon is the drug of choice for treating insomnia in blind individuals due to its effectiveness in regulating the sleep-wake cycle by acting as a melatonin receptor agonist, particularly in those with Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder.

questions.text: The most appropriate expansion of Apgar is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, respiration

 

  • The expansion of Apgar is appearance, pulse, grimace, activity and respiration.

 

 

 

The APGAR score is a quick assessment of a newborn's overall health and well-being immediately after birth. The score is based on a five-point scale that evaluates the newborn's appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. Each category is scored from 0-2, and the total score ranges from 0-10. A score of 7 or above is considered normal, while a score of 4-6 indicates that the newborn may require some medical attention, and a score of 3 or below indicates that the newborn requires immediate medical attention. The APGAR score is typically assessed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth and may be repeated if necessary.Top of FormBottom of Form

 

Educational Objective:


The Apgar score assesses a newborn's health based on five criteria: Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by abnormal diastolic filling with relatively preserved systolic function. The histology often shows increased myocardial stiffness due to fibrosis, which is evident as diffuse fibrotic deposition within the myocardium. The cardiac muscle appears normal in size or slightly hypertrophic without significant dilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Typically shows dilated heart chambers and significant myocardial thinning with fibrosis, which is not evident in the provided histology image.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Characterized by marked hypertrophy of the myocardium, especially the septum.

 

Option D. Atrial fibrillation: This is primarily an electrical disorder of the heart, typically not diagnosed via myocardial biopsy and does not have a distinctive histopathological appearance related to the rhythm disorder itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In restrictive cardiomyopathy, the key histological feature is myocardial fibrosis leading to stiffening of the heart muscle, which impacts its ability to fill properly during diastole, though systolic function might be preserved.

questions.text: Which of the following is a novel anti-depressant? (INICET Nov 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vilazodone

 

Vilazodone is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor as well as a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist. It is a new antidepressant. It does not have the side effect of erectile dysfunction.

 

Vortioxetine is another example of a novel antidepressant, that apart from being a SSRI, acts on multiple other receptors of serotonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Lurasidone, Asenapine and Pimavanserin are examples of atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option A. Lurasidone: This is an atypical antipsychotic, primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. While it can be used to treat depressive episodes in bipolar disorder, it is not primarily categorized as an antidepressant.

 

Option C. Asenapine: Asenapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It is not classified as an antidepressant.

 

Option D. Pimavanserin: This is an atypical antipsychotic and inverse agonist and antagonist of the serotonin receptors. It is primarily used in the treatment of psychosis in patients with Parkinson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vilazodone is a novel antidepressant with a dual mechanism of action, functioning as both an SSRI and a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist, making it effective for treating depression with fewer sexual side effects. Other Options listed are atypical antipsychotics and not classified as antidepressants.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous steroids

 

  • Intravenous steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.
  • Etiology: exogenous infection (trauma, surgery), endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis, secondary infections from surrounding structures.
  • Cardinal features: pain, lid swelling, diminished vision.
  • Maintain high index of suspicion, especially in postoperative cases, and treat empirically with antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

 

Treatment

 

All cases are treated empirically with a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics and corticosteroids from the beginning. The aim is to maintain a high intraocular concentration of antibiotics throughout treatment.

 

  • Therapeutic regimen 
    • Topical antibiotics: Fortified cefazolin or vancomycin with gentamicin or amikacin.
    • Topical atropine: for cycloplegia.
    • Subconjunctival antibiotics: not frequently used.
    • Intravitreal antibiotics: The treatment of choice and are injected after taking vitreous aspirate for preparing smears and obtaining cultures. A combination of vancomycin and ceftazidime is preferred. Amikacin or gentamicin is used less frequently (risk of macular infarction). Simultaneous injection of dexamethasone is optional.
    • Intravitreal injection of amphotericin B: In suspected fungal aetiology, without the use of any adjunctive steroids.
    • Oral antifungals: Given, if fungal cultures are positive.
    • Vitrectomy: Hastens bacterial and fungal endophthalmitis recovery.
    • Corticosteroids: 
      • Some authorities recommend the combined use of corticosteroids from the outset (unless there is a strong clinical suspicion of a fungal aetiology in which case steroids should be withheld), while others prefer to wait for a confirmed positive clinical response to antibiotic therapy before administering steroids over the next 24–48 hours.
      • The rationale for corticosteroid therapy derives from its anti-inflammatory effects, leading to preservation of the ocular structures.
      • Routes of administration are:
        1. Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone
        2. Subconjunctival injection of dexamethasone
        3. Topical dexamethasone or predacetate
        4. Oral prednisolone
    • Patients need to be reviewed every 4–8 hours. The visual outcome depends on the duration between the onset of infection and institution of therapy, and the nature of the infecting organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A Intravitreal antibiotic injection: This is a standard treatment for endophthalmitis, involving direct administration of antibiotics into the eye to quickly achieve high intraocular concentrations, crucial for combating the infection.

 

Option C. Pars plana vitrectomy: Often recommended for severe cases, this surgical intervention can remove infectious agents and inflammatory debris directly from the vitreous, thereby reducing bacterial load and improving drug penetration.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotic: Used to provide high local concentrations of antibiotics at the site of infection, though not sufficient alone for severe cases, they support the main treatment regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For endophthalmitis following ocular surgery, intravitreal antibiotics are crucial, while systemic steroids are generally avoided due to the risk of exacerbating the infection.

questions.text: A patient with ascites is found to have SAAG ≥ 1.1. All of the following causes except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TB peritonitis

 

The Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is calculated to differentiate between ascites caused by portal hypertension (high SAAG ≥ 1.1) and ascites caused by other reasons (low SAAG < 1.1). A SAAG value ≥ 1.1 indicates that the ascites is likely due to issues related to portal hypertension, such as cirrhosis, liver failure, or metastasis to the liver, which can also cause portal hypertension. Tuberculosis peritonitis, however, typically presents with a SAAG lower than 1.1 because it is not associated with portal hypertension but rather with peritoneal inflammation and capillary leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Directly associated with portal hypertension and commonly results in a SAAG ≥ 1.1.

 

Option B. Liver failure: Often leads to portal hypertension, causing a high SAAG.

 

Option C. Metastasis to liver: Can impede hepatic blood flow and increase portal pressure, also leading to a high SAAG.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Right internal jugular vein
Cervical sympathetic chain
Left vagus nerve
Right internal carotid artery

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

 

In hanging, the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic Ganglion, this causes eye on the same side to remain open and pupil dilated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right internal jugular vein: Compression would cause venous congestion but is not directly related to the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option C. Left vagus nerve: Compression would affect parasympathetic innervation, potentially leading to bradycardia, but not the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option D. Right internal carotid artery: Compression could lead to ischemia, but it does not explain the unilateral open eye and pupil dilation.

 

Educational Objective

 

PM findings of hanging in the Neck

 

  • Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • La facies sympathique
  • Salivary dribbling
  • Ligature mark
  • Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Hyoid bone fracture

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium.
  • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy.
  • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women with bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasonography should prompt further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 357

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus
Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of scoliosis. Given below is the erect X-ray abdomen radiograph of the lady. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus

 

The given clinical scenario with an elderly woman and the radiograph showing characteristic coffee bean appearance are highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus causing a large bowel obstruction.

 

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. The onset may be acute or chronic. It occurs more commonly in patients with a history of mental illness and chronic constipation.

 

X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign, Frimann-Dahl sign (three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction), and the absence of rectal gas. CT may reveal a large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Fecolith (a hardened mass of stool) is more likely to cause appendicitis or obstruction at the ileocecal valve rather than in the sigmoid colon. Fecolith obstruction does not commonly result in the characteristic "coffee bean" appearance on imaging.

 

Option C. Cecal volvulus: While this is another form of volvulus, it is less common than sigmoid volvulus. Cecal volvulus typically occurs in younger patients and presents with a different radiological appearance, including haustral markings and a different orientation of the twisted bowel.

 

Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Small bowel obstruction does not typically show the "coffee bean" sign seen in sigmoid volvulus. Additionally, perforation would likely show free air under the diaphragm, which is not indicated in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "coffee bean sign" seen on X-ray is a characteristic feature of sigmoid volvulus, a condition where the sigmoid colon twists on itself, causing large bowel obstruction.

questions.text:
What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? (INICET May 2023)

 

1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute

2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute

3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm

4. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

 

Explanation:

 

High-Quality CPR Indicators:

 

1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

 

3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).

 

4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.

 

Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle accident. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires a massive blood transfusion. The physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of the transfusion and wants to monitor the patient closely. The physician wants to confirm which of the following adverse effects is not commonly observed in patients who receive a massive blood transfusion? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

This is not a common adverse effect of blood transfusions. Blood transfusions are more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to citrate binding calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemia: It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because citrate, an anticoagulant used in blood storage bags, can bind to calcium, reducing its levels when the transfused blood is administered. Citrate is used to prevent blood clotting during storage but can have this effect when transfused.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: It can rarely occur after a massive blood transfusion because of dilution of recipient’s blood potassium.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: This is a potential adverse effect of a massive blood transfusion. Stored blood cells can undergo lysis leading to higher potassium levels in the blood products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypocalcemia and not Hypercalcemia is an adverse effect of massive blood transfusion.
  • Massive blood transfusion instead leads to Hypocalcemia as the anticoagulant citrate binds to calcium.

 

The complications of massive blood transfusion are:

 

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

 

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis that catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Its activity is increased in the fed state and decreased during fasting. During fasting, the body's metabolic state shifts to prioritize gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation, leading to a decrease in glycolytic enzyme activities, including PFK-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Mobilizes fatty acids from adipose tissue by breaking down triglycerides.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in the liver and muscles, providing glucose during fasting.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a key step in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding chalazion? 

 

  1. Always Painful
  2. Can occur in the upper or lower eyelid
  3. Hair follicle inflammation
  4. Meibomian Gland Inflammation
  5. Always treated with antibiotics
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  2, 4

 

A chalazion is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland. It presents as a painless swelling in the eyelid and can occur in both the upper and lower eyelids due to blockage and inflammation of the Meibomian glands, not hair follicles.

 

  • Statement 2 (Can occur in the upper or lower eyelid): True. A chalazion can develop in either the upper or lower eyelid.
  • Statement 4 (Meibomian Gland Inflammation): True. Chalazion is specifically an inflammation of the Meibomian glands, which are responsible for secreting oils into the tears.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1. Always Painful: Incorrect. A chalazion is generally painless, unlike a stye which is often painful.

 

Statement 3. Hair follicle inflammation: Incorrect. Hair follicle inflammation pertains to a stye, not a chalazion.

 

Statement 5. Always treated with antibiotics: Incorrect. Chalazion treatment typically involves incision and curettage or steroid injection rather than antibiotics, as it is not usually due to an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A chalazion is a painless inflammation of the Meibomian gland and can appear on either the upper or lower eyelid.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A new combined treatment regimen of chemotherapy and immunotherapy has significantly increased survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. If the number of new cases remains consistent, but patients live longer, which epidemiological impact would be observed? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • Due to the new drug combination, patient survival rates have risen, resulting in a situation where the incidence remains unchanged while prevalence sees an increase.

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Since New cases will keep on occurring at the same rate, Incidence will remain same. Duration will increase (as survival increases). So, overall Prevalence will increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When patient survival increases due to a new treatment, the incidence of the disease remains the same, but the prevalence increases due to longer survival duration.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are three permeable ions. X = -50 and Y = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic transfer, what is the value of Z? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) + 80

 

No net electrogenic transfer at RMP implies that X + Y + Z = 0

 

So, - 50 + (-30) + Z =0

 

Z = 50 + 30 = 80

 

Educational Objective:

 

No net electrogenic transfer at resting membrane potential (RMP) implies that the sum of the equilibrium potentials of the ions is zero

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
There is no pain on ocular movement.
Multiple myeloma is a common cause.
Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

 

In optic neuritis, relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil is seen. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD, both pupils dilate when moving the flashlight from the normal eye to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is known as Marcus Gunn pupil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain is actually aggravated by ocular movement:  particularly in upward or downward directions due to the attachment of the superior rectus muscle to the dura mater.

 

Option C. Multiple sclerosis: not multiple myeloma, is a well-known demyelinating cause of optic neuritis. Multiple sclerosis often presents with optic neuritis as an early sign.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is contraindicated:  because it does not improve the outcome and is associated with an increased risk of new attacks of optic neuritis. Instead, intravenous methylprednisolone can be used, especially in patients showing radiological evidence of multiple sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also called Marcus Gunn pupil, is a key diagnostic finding in optic neuritis, and multiple sclerosis is the common cause of this condition.

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for a 26-year-old woman who was brought to the ER at Hospital after a car accident, with a stable blood pressure, a GCS score of 3, and a normal non-contrast CT scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse axonal injury

 

The patient's clinical presentation suggests the possibility of diffuse axonal injury, which occurs when the brain experiences shearing forces, often from rotational acceleration within the skull. This can result in damage to the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule, leading to disruption of axons and microvasculature.

 

 Automobile accidents are the most common cause of diffuse axonal injury, and patients often remain unconscious from the moment of impact until death. Multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution are typical of diffuse axonal injury, and CT scans may appear normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), particularly susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), is the preferred imaging modality for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury, and can reveal small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage. Subdural hemorrhage, extradural hemorrhage, and cerebral contusion are other potential traumatic brain injuries that can present with different imaging features and may require different treatments.

 

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from the shearing forces during rapid deceleration or rotational head trauma. It can cause profound neurological impairment, even with a seemingly normal CT scan early on. A GCS score of 3 is indicative of severe brain injury, and DAI is a common cause of such a presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage is associated with bleeding between the brain and its outermost covering (the dura mater). While it can result from head trauma, it typically presents with altered mental status, neurological deficits, or focal symptoms. A GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Extradural hemorrhage: It can lead to rapid neurological deterioration, often with a lucid interval after the injury. A normal non-contrast CT scan is inconsistent with an acute extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Cerebral contusion: Cerebral contusions are focal brain injuries characterized by bruising of the brain tissue. They can occur in head trauma and may present with neurological deficits or focal symptoms. However, a normal non-contrast CT scan would typically not rule out a cerebral contusion if it's a small or subtle contusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's presentation with a GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan, the most probable diagnosis is diffuse axonal injury (option C), which can result in severe neurological impairment despite a normal initial CT scan.

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+

 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

 

  1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with metastatic melanoma and begins a newly developed combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy. His oncologist explains that this treatment significantly prolongs survival. Which of the following statements best describes the expected impact of this treatment on the epidemiological metrics of melanoma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

The introduction of the new drug combination improves survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. This means that more people will live longer with the disease, which directly increases prevalence—the total number of people living with the disease at a given time.

 

Since the treatment does not prevent the disease from occurring, the incidence—the rate of new cases—remains unchanged. Therefore, with longer survival but no change in the rate of new cases, the overall prevalence will rise.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time
  • Prevalence: Is total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over a point or period of time
  • Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence: Given the assumption that population is stable AND incidence & duration are unchanging,

 

Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of the disease

 

P = I × d

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below used in laparoscopic surgeries? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The instrument in the image is Veress Needle.

 

The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. It consists of a long, slender needle with a sharp, pointed tip and a hollow center. The needle is attached to a handle and a valve that controls the flow of gas into the abdominal cavity.

 

The Veress needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity through a small incision, usually in the umbilicus (closed technique). The surgeon first lifts the abdominal wall away from the underlying organs and tissues, then inserts the Veress needle at a 45-degree angle to the skin and advances it until it reaches the abdominal cavity. The valve is then opened to allow gas (usually carbon dioxide) to flow into the abdominal cavity, creating a space for the laparoscope and other instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morris' needle: This is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum or laparoscopic access.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction tip: This is a suction instrument used to clear surgical sites of blood and fluids, not for gas insufflation.

 

Option D. Von Graefe needle: Primarily used in ophthalmic procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of the Veress needle helps to minimize the risk of injury to surrounding organs and tissues during laparoscopic procedures. It is typically used at the beginning of the procedure, after which the laparoscope and other instruments are inserted through separate ports or trocars placed in the abdomen. The Veress needle is then removed and the incision closed.

questions.text: Which drug is used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by daunorubicin? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexrazoxane

 

Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used specifically to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline chemotherapy agents like daunorubicin. It protects the heart by reducing the formation of free radicals that can damage cardiac tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aprepitant: Aprepitant is utilized to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. It works as a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist but does not have a role in preventing cardiotoxicity from chemotherapeutic drugs.

 

Option C. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent that offers protection against the toxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy on normal tissues, particularly for kidneys and salivary glands, but it is not indicated for the prevention of cardiotoxicity from daunorubicin.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. In oncology, it is often used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and to treat certain cancer-related conditions, but it is not used to prevent daunorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexrazoxane is specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by anthracycline chemotherapy agents such as daunorubicin by reducing free radical formation and oxidative stress on the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be observed in a patient diagnosed with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leukemia

 

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) patients can progress to leukemia, but never present with it.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: This is a possible complication in patients with PNH. The disease can be associated with aplastic anemia, which involves pancytopenia and bone marrow failure.

 

Option C. Thrombosis: Thrombosis, particularly in unusual sites like the hepatic veins (Budd-Chiari syndrome), is a common and severe complication of PNH. It is one of the leading causes of mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Hemolysis: Chronic intravascular hemolysis is a hallmark of PNH, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, hemoglobinuria (often seen as dark-colored urine, especially in the morning), and anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with PNH frequently experience hemolysis, thrombosis, and can develop aplastic anemia. While leukemia can occur as a later complication, it is not a typical presenting feature of PNH.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1213

questions.text: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18,31,33,45,52,58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/news/item/20-12-2022-WHO-updates-recommendations-on-HPV-vaccination-schedule

choices.text: Western blot
Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following method is employed to measure the viral load? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Real time PCR

 

A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time). Fluorescence is measured after each cycle and the intensity of the fluorescent signal reflects the momentary amount of DNA amplicons in the sample at that specific time. Commonly used for viral load quantification of HIV, hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, and CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. ELISA: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay is primarily used to detect antigens or antibodies in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option B. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option D. Immunoelectrophoresis: This method is used to separate and identify proteins based on their antigen-antibody interactions and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Real-time PCR measure viral load
  • Western blotting – detects protein.
  • ELISA - detect antigens of infectious agents
  • Immuno electrophoresis – separates antigen following antigen antibody reaction

choices.text: Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS
Start Antihypertensives and ARM

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

 

Explanation:

 

Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.

 

Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.

 

Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drugs act at the site marked by the arrow? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tiagabine

 

Explanation: 


Tiagabine acts by inhibiting GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1), which is responsible for the reuptake of GABA from the synapse. By blocking this transporter, Tiagabine increases the synaptic concentration of GABA, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and providing antiepileptic effects. The name "Tiagabine" itself suggests its mechanism - Transport Inhibitor of GABA or GAT-1 inhibitor.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Vigabatrin: Incorrect. It inhibits GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, not the GABA transporter. This increases GABA levels through a different mechanism.

 

 

Option B. Valproate: Incorrect. It has multiple mechanisms of action, primarily involving sodium channel blockade and enhancement of GABA-mediated inhibition, but does not specifically target GAT-1.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist and enhances GABA-mediated inhibition through different mechanisms, not through GAT-1 inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:


Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake by blocking the GABA transporter (GAT-1), leading to increased extracellular GABA and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission, making it an effective treatment for epilepsy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss and looked jaundiced. Upon further investigation, you suspect a parasitic infection. You obtain a stool sample and operculated eggs in the feces. Further examination reveals the presence of a parasite with a complex life cycle with snail and plants as the intermediate host. Which parasite is most likely responsible for the above symptoms? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica

 

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.

 

Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

 

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation.

 

Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

 

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fasciolopsis buski: Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke, and while it also involves snails as intermediate hosts, it does not primarily target the liver. Infection typically occurs through ingestion of aquatic plants, but the symptoms and life cycle do not match those described.

 

Option C. Paragonimus westermani: Paragonimus westermani, the lung fluke, has a complex life cycle involving snails and crustaceans. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms rather than abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Eggs are typically found in sputum, not feces.

 

Option D. Clonorchis sinensis: Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, also involves snails as intermediate hosts and can cause liver-related symptoms. However, the life cycle and specific hosts differ slightly from Fasciola hepatica. It primarily affects the liver and bile ducts but is more common in certain geographic regions.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air


Severe COVID-19 is characterized by a significant drop in oxygen saturation. An SpO2 of less than 85% on room air indicates severe hypoxemia.

 

Any SpO2 of less than 90% indicate severe COVID and 90-93% indicates moderate COVID

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RR >24/min: Indicates moderate, not severe, COVID-19. RR>30/min indicate severe COVID
 

Option B. MAP 70 mmHg: Does not specifically indicate severe COVID-19. Hemodynamic instability i.e. MAP <65 OR 65 or above with vasopressors indicates severe COVID. 
 

Option C. Lung infiltrates >42% on CT: Not a specific criterion for COVID-19 severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypopyon  

 

The finding seen in the image is hypopyon.

 

  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically seen in the lower part of the chamber as a whitish exudate.
  • In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungus can penetrate into the anterior chamber without causing a perforation.
  • Hypopyon associated with anterior uveitis is immobile because of the high fibrin content in the exudate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Hyphema is a hemorrhage in the anterior chamber. It commonly occurs after a blunt ocular injury. The bleeding is from the iris root or ciliary body face. The blood settles inferiorly forming a fluid level.

 

 

Option B: Aqueous flare refers to the haziness of the normally clear fluid in the anterior chamber. It reflects the presence of protein due to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier. The presence of flare indicates active inflammation.

 

Option C: Arlt line is the scarring on the conjunctiva in the area of sulcus subtarsalis. It can be a single line, irregularly shaped, or star-shaped. Common causes are trachoma, healed traumatic wounds, or surgical scars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 849

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is the diagnosis in this case, which is characterized by an open, inside-out bladder on the surface of the lower abdominal wall, and an exposed dorsal urethra. The pathogenesis of this condition is thought to be due to an embryological defect in abdominal wall development. In affected females, there is epispadias with bifid clitoris and small, laterally displaced labia minora, while in affected males, there is epispadias as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrochisis: The abdominal contents will be out and not covered in a sac.

 

 

 

Option C. Superior vesical fissure: A defect of closure in the infra-umbilical abdominal wall through which vesical mucous membrane protruded. A probe introduced into the urethra appeared externally at the place of the infraumbilical defect. Following the diagnosis of superior vesical fissure, resection of the protruding vesical mucous membrane and closure were carried out.

 

Option D. Anterior ectopic anus: The above features and image doesn’t correlate with the mentioned findings in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Bladder exstrophy presents as an exposed, inside-out bladder on the abdominal wall, often associated with continuous dribbling of urine, especially in female newborns with epispadias and bifid clitoris.

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.
