Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

choices.text: Unfractionated Heparin
Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Low molecular weight heparin

 

LMWH is the anticoagulant of choice for the treatment of Cancer associated thromboembolism. It has a long half-life, higher bioavailability and does not require anticoagulant monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated Heparin: While effective, it requires continuous intravenous infusion and frequent monitoring of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), making it less convenient for long-term management.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin requires regular monitoring of the international normalized ratio (INR) to maintain therapeutic levels, which can be challenging in cancer patients due to potential drug interactions and varying dietary intake.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. Although effective, it is not the first choice for cancer-associated thromboembolism due to limited evidence compared to LMWH and potential for drug interactions and gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for managing cancer-associated thromboembolism due to its long half-life, higher bioavailability, and the convenience of not requiring routine anticoagulant monitoring.

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after an RTA. He has suffered chest trauma, has respiratory rate of 44/min and BP is 90/40 mm of hg. He is conscious and speaks single words. There is a hyper-resonance on percussion on the involved side of his chest. What will be your immediate next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercoastal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia
  2. Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum - infants
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is closely associated with giant cell arteritis in women above 50yrs.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia: Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, particularly in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia. The virus affects erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia in these patients.

 

3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe fetal complications, including hydrops fetalis, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe edema in the fetus.

 

4. Erythema infectiosum - infants: Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease, is a common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection in young children, not just infants. It presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically seen in women above 50 years old and is not related to parvovirus infection in young women. Parvovirus B19 is more commonly associated with conditions such as erythema infectiosum in children, pure red cell aplasia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.

 

Additional Information

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High estrogen


Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited primarily by high estrogen levels. Although prolactin, an anterior pituitary hormone, is responsible for stimulating milk production (lactogenesis), high levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy prevent the secretion of milk. Estrogen promotes the development of the mammary glands but suppresses milk production. After childbirth, the levels of estrogen and progesterone drop, which allows prolactin to initiate and sustain milk secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low luteinizing hormone: Incorrect. Luteinizing hormone (LH) is not directly involved in the regulation of milk production. The primary inhibitors are estrogen and progesterone.

 

Option C. Human somatomammotropin: Incorrect. Human somatomammotropin (also known as human placental lactogen) supports breast development and promotes milk production but does not inhibit it.

 

Option D. Low thyroid-stimulating hormone: Incorrect. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is not a primary factor in inhibiting milk production during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:


High estrogen levels inhibit milk production during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: All of the following features are observed in pleomorphic adenoma except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineural invasion

 

Perineural invasion is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma.

 

 

Note - Perineural invasion is seen in malignant salivary gland tumors like adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myoepithelial cells: Present in pleomorphic adenomas, contributing to the tumor's mixed epithelial and mesenchymal characteristics.

 

Option B. Keratin pearls: While not typically a feature of pleomorphic adenomas, the presence of keratin can be associated with the epithelial component. However, keratin pearls are more characteristic of squamous cell carcinomas.

 

Option C. Chondroid differentiation: A hallmark of pleomorphic adenomas, where the tumor shows cartilaginous differentiation, often contributing to its benign nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Pleomorphic adenomas are characterized by a mixture of epithelial and mesenchymal components, including myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but they do not exhibit perineural invasion, which is more typical of malignant salivary gland tumors.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1436-1437

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days
Admit and observe
Follow-up with beta-HCG

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

The patient presents with symptoms that could indicate either an ectopic pregnancy or an early miscarriage. The absence of a gestational sac in the uterus on ultrasound at 6 weeks' gestation warrants further investigation to determine the location and viability of the pregnancy. The most appropriate next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ectopic Pregnancy vs. Early Miscarriage: The differential diagnosis includes both ectopic pregnancy and early miscarriage.
  • Serial Beta-HCG Measurement: Beta-HCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours in a normal early intrauterine pregnancy. An abnormal rise or plateau in beta-HCG levels may indicate an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy.
  • Ultrasound Follow-up: In combination with beta-HCG monitoring, follow-up ultrasounds can help determine if a gestational sac becomes visible in the uterus or elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: Declaring a complete abortion without further investigation is premature and may miss an ectopic pregnancy, which can have serious complications.

 

Option B. Admit and observe: While observation is important, serial beta-HCG levels provide critical information that can guide further management decisions.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure and is not the first step in stable patients without definitive evidence of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 356

choices.text: BP > 160/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP > 160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives.

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above goal despite the concurrent use of three anti-hypertensive agents of different classes. Typically, one of the three medications should be a diuretic, and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts. The threshold set for defining resistant hypertension is blood pressure greater than 140/90 mmHg.

 

Resistant hypertension indicates a situation where blood pressure control is inadequate despite the use of multiple medications, which can pose significant risks for cardiovascular complications and requires careful evaluation for secondary causes. This includes assessing for white-coat HTN/Pseudo HTN, medication adherence, lifestyle factors, and secondary causes of hypertension like renal artery stenosis, endocrine disorders, or medication-induced hypertension.

 

Home BP monitoring, ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring) can help in optimization of drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistant HTN refers to BP > 140/90 mmHg despite three anti-HTN, one being a diuretic.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Cardiology/Hypertensive Disease/ chap 277

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Banana sign on USG associated with? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spina bifida

 

Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect / spinal dysraphism which can occur to varying degrees of severity. It is often considered the most common congenital CNS malformation.

 

Banana sign - Refers to the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis, which appears elongated and curved, resembling the shape of a banana.

 

Lemon sign - In prenatal ultrasound, when spina bifida is present, the base of the skull can appear abnormal and shaped like a lemon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where abdominal contents protrude into the umbilical cord. This condition is associated with various ultrasound findings, but not specifically with the Banana sign.

 

Option C. Down’s syndrome: Characterized by the presence of an extra chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), Down’s syndrome has associated ultrasound markers like increased nuchal translucency and absent nasal bone, but not the Banana sign.

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome: A genetic condition affecting males, characterized by an extra X chromosome (XXY). This condition is typically identified through genetic testing and is not associated with the Banana sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Banana sign" on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida and represents the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis. It is a critical ultrasound finding suggestive of spina bifida and should be carefully evaluated alongside other signs such as the "Lemon sign," which depicts an abnormal skull shape resembling a lemon, also indicative of neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate termination

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described indicates fetal compromise, specifically with the findings of oligohydramnios (AFI = 5) and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler. These are signs of severe placental insufficiency and fetal distress.

 

  • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth.
  • Management:
    • Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks: This is not appropriate because the immediate risk to the fetus requires prompt delivery.

 

Option C. Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion: Continuous monitoring is insufficient in this scenario as the condition indicates severe fetal distress requiring urgent intervention.

 

Option D. Terminate after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is not appropriate due to the immediate risk of fetal compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe fetal compromise indicated by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler, especially beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate termination of the pregnancy is warranted to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential stillbirth.

 

Ref: Page no 2141, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Compartment syndrome is rare.
  2. Immediate debridement should be done.
  3. Tibia is the most common long bone involved.
  4. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

 

I. Compartment syndrome is rare: True

 

  • In open fractures, the fascia may be disrupted, which reduces the risk of rising compartment pressure.

  • However, compartment syndrome can still occur, especially in high-energy injuries, so it is not impossible, but it is less common compared to closed fractures.

 

II. Immediate debridement should be done: True

 

  • Early and thorough surgical debridement is the cornerstone of open fracture management to reduce infection risk.

  • Ideally performed within 6–8 hours, though recent evidence suggests that a short delay may not significantly change infection rates if antibiotics are given promptly.

 

III. Tibia is the most common long bone involved: True

 

  • The tibia is the most commonly involved long bone in open fractures due to its subcutaneous location (minimal soft tissue coverage).

  • Therefore, it’s more vulnerable to open injuries, especially in road traffic accidents.

 

IV. Multiple fractures are uncommon: False

  • Multiple fractures are actually common, particularly in high-energy trauma like road traffic accidents, falls from height, or blast injuries.

  • Open fractures often occur as part of polytrauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text: Identify the given ECG? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Torsade’s de pointes

 

Torsade’s de pointes is characterized by a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with varying QRS complex amplitudes and a twisting around the baseline.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Characterized by a chaotic and irregular waveform without identifiable QRS complexes.
 

Option C. Atrial flutter: Shows a sawtooth pattern of atrial activity.
 

Option D. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: Shows uniform QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Torsade’s de pointes are a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic twisting pattern.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Labia majora - separated
  • Labia minora- flabby
  • Fourchette tear present
  • Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen

 

What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False virgin

 

The observed separated labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not a virgin. Despite having sexual intercourse, the hymen is intact so it is a case of false virgin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True virgin: Presence of labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not true virgin.

 

Option C. Premenstrual change typically involve hormonal variations leading to breast tenderness, bloating, and mood swings rather than observable alterations in genital anatomy.

 

Option D. Molestation there would be sign of abrasions, bruising, edema, laceration or may have injuries to the vulva, hymen, vagina and the perineum. Since these signs are not present chances of molestation are slim

 

Educational  Objective:

 

Please note that the features will be same for a deflorate woman and a false virgin with the exception of presence of hymen in the latter.

choices.text: Central capillary dilatation → Wheal → Surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare.

questions.text: On performing a Histamine test on an individual with brachial plexus trunk injury, you can expect? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare

 

In patient with brachial plexus trunk injury, there is anesthesia over the skin in that region. Histamine test in this patient will result in capillary dilatation and wheal without surrounding flare.

 

Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin which includes a red reaction, flare and wheal.

 

  • Red reaction is because of capillary dilatation and is independent of innervation.
  • Flare reaction is due to dilatation of arterioles caused by the axon reflex.
  • Axon reflex or antidromic reflex is the process by which the impulses are conducted in a direction opposite to the normal direction. Normally, the impulses produced by a cutaneous pain receptor pass through sensory nerve fiber towards the nerve cell body in posterior nerve root ganglion. Some of these impulses pass through the other branches of the same fiber in the opposite direction and reach the blood vessels supplied by these branches. Impulses now dilate the blood vessels. This is called the antidromic or axon reflex. Thus, flare is absent in anesthetized skin.
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to increased capillary permeability

 

The triple response can be seen after total sympathectomy

 

The incomplete triple response over the anesthetic skin is characteristic of postganglionic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a brachial plexus trunk injury, the histamine test will result in central capillary dilatation and a wheal without the surrounding flare due to the disruption of the axon reflex.

questions.text: What is the main action of the muscle marked below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Elevation

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis and its main action is elevation of the mandible.

 

Other actions are:

 

  • ﻿﻿It helps in the side-to-side grinding movements of the mandible.
  • ﻿﻿The posterior fibres which are horizontal, help in the retraction of the mandible.

 

The muscles of mastication are a group of four muscles that are responsible for the movements of the jaw during chewing (mastication). These muscles include:

 

Together, these muscles work to elevate and depress the mandible, move it side to side, and protrude it forward. They are important for chewing, speaking, and swallowing. Dysfunction of these muscles can result in temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders and other oral health problems.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: This action is not associated with the temporalis muscle. Depression of the mandible, which involves opening the jaw, is primarily accomplished by the digastric muscle and, to some extent, by the lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

Option C. Protrusion: Protrusion refers to pushing the jaw forward. This action is chiefly performed by the lateral pterygoid muscle, not the temporalis.

 

Option D. Retraction: While the posterior fibers of the temporalis muscle do assist in retraction of the mandible, pulling it backward, it is not the primary action of the entire muscle. The main retractor of the jaw is the posterior part of the temporalis muscle alongside the digastric muscle (posterior belly).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Constricted pupils and bradycardia

 

Dilated pupils and tachycardia is seen with cocaine ingestion as it is a sympathomimetic (stimulant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling and numbness of hands and feet: This is a common symptom due to the neurological effects of cocaine.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Cocaine causes vasoconstriction and increased heart rate, leading to hypertension.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: Increased body temperature is a common finding due to excessive sympathetic stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of cocaine intoxication:

 

  • Early features – Stage of excitement:
  • Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
  • Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death.
  • Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin.
  • Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse

choices.text: Collagen is a type of fibrous protein, which is most abundant of all human proteins
Post translational hydroxylation of proline & lysine
Triple helix is required for its function

questions.text: Which of the following is false about collagen: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

 

Collagen is a fibrous protein that is indeed the most abundant protein in the human body. It provides structural support to various tissues, including skin, bones, tendons, and blood vessels. However, the most abundant amino acid in collagen is actually glycine, not phenylalanine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collagen is a type of fibrous protein that is the most abundant protein in the human body. It forms a strong and flexible structure in various tissues.

 

Option C. Post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues is an essential process in collagen synthesis. This hydroxylation is necessary for the proper formation and stability of collagen's triple helix structure.

 

Option D. The triple helix structure is a characteristic feature of collagen and is crucial for its function. Collagen molecules are composed of three polypeptide chains, coiled around each other in a triple helical arrangement. This structure provides collagen with its strength and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the correct composition of collagen is essential to understand its structural role in the human body.

questions.text: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycythemia vera

 

Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

The exact etiology of PV is not known but about a third of cases show inconsistent and varied chromosomal abnormalities such as 20q, trisomy 8 and 9p. Major pathogenetic mechanism is a tyrosine kinase JAK2 mutation which removes the autoinhibitory control and activates the kinases.

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is an acquired, somatic mutation present in the majority of patients with myeloproliferative cancer (myeloproliferative neoplasms) i.e. nearly 100% of patients with polycythemia vera and in about 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis and primary myelofibrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential thrombocytosis: The JAK2 V617F mutation is also found in approximately 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis, but it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Option C. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia): CML is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22) translocation), not the JAK2 mutation.

 

Option D. PMF (Primary Myelofibrosis): The JAK2 mutation is present in about 50% of patients with PMF, but again, it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is most commonly associated with polycythemia vera, where it drives the excessive production of red blood cells through constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1161

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries: [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

  1. Walter Reed showed that yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.
  2. Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human genome project?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It took 2 years to discover

 

  • Explanation: Option D is false. The Human Genome Project did not take only 2 years to complete. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade. The official launch of the project was in 1990, and a working draft of the human genome was announced in 2000. The project was completed in 2003.
  • Relevance: This statement is false, and the actual timeline of the Human Genome Project demonstrates that it was a multi-year, collaborative effort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collaboration of Many Countries:

 

  • Explanation: The Human Genome Project was indeed a collaborative effort involving many countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others. It aimed to map and sequence the entire human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects the international nature of the project.

 

Option B. 20,000 Total Genes Were Identified :

 

  • Explanation: During the Human Genome Project, it was estimated that there are approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes in the human genome. This estimate is relatively accurate, considering the complexity of the human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects one of the significant achievements of the HGP.

 

Option C. It Uses Modern Sequencing Techniques:

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The project initially started with Sanger sequencing, which was state-of-the-art at the time.
  • Towards the end and afterward, next-generation sequencing (NGS) evolved, further enhancing genome studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Human genome project started in 1990 and completed with sequence of Y chromosome this year in 2022. So, it took > 2 decades. This was a collaborative project spread across many labs in different countries across world. Approximately 22000 genes were identified in entire Human genome using High throughput Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) techniques.

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 98

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capnography

 

Explanation:

 

Capnography primarily measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, which gives information about ventilation and metabolism. It does not measure cardiac output. Capnography is commonly used to monitor end-tidal CO2 and confirm tracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thermal dilution technique: The thermal dilution technique is a method used primarily with a pulmonary artery catheter (also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter). Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature is measured as it passes a thermistor in the pulmonary artery. The degree of temperature change allows for the calculation of cardiac output. This method is invasive and provides continuous or intermittent measurements, depending on the specific catheter and monitor used.

 

Option C. Esophageal Doppler: The esophageal Doppler uses ultrasound waves to measure blood flow velocity in the descending aorta via a probe placed in the esophagus. By knowing the cross-sectional area of the aorta and calculating the velocity of blood flow, cardiac output can be estimated.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography, or cardiac ultrasound, allows for visualization of cardiac structures and blood flow. Cardiac output can be estimated by measuring the velocity of blood flow across the mitral or tricuspid valves and then multiplying this by the valve area.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air and is not used to determine cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is affected in pancreas of a patient with Cystic Fibrosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The part labelled 'B' in the image is the acini (exocrine pancreas) which is affected in cystic fibrosis.

 

 

In Cystic Fibrosis, there is accumulation mucin in ducts of pancreas which leads to atrophy of exocrine pancreas.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: Likely corresponds to a blood vessel, which is not primarily affected in CF.

 

Option C. C: Corresponds to a larger duct, which may also be obstructed by mucus, but the question specifically asks about the structure most commonly affected, which is the acini.

 

Option D. D: May correspond to an islet of Langerhans (endocrine pancreas), which is less commonly affected in the early stages of CF compared to the exocrine acini.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Cystic Fibrosis, the acini (exocrine pancreas) are primarily affected due to mucus accumulation in the ducts, leading to atrophy and fibrosis of the exocrine pancreas.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is brought into the emergency department with acute myocardial infarction and has received fibrinolytic therapy. The patient begins to experience excessive bleeding post-therapy. Which of the following is the best antidote to reverse the effects of fibrinolytic therapy? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epsilon-aminocaproic acid

 

Epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA) is a potent inhibitor of fibrinolysis and is used to counteract the effects of fibrinolytic agents such as streptokinase or tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). It works by inhibiting plasminogen activation, preventing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby halting the breakdown of fibrin clots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine: This drug is primarily used to reverse the effects of heparin, not fibrinolytic agents.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Streptokinase is a fibrinolytic agent and is used to dissolve clots. It would exacerbate bleeding, not treat it.

 

Option C. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent clot formation. It is unrelated to fibrinolytic therapy and does not serve as an antidote for bleeding complications from fibrinolytic drugs.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Epsilon-aminocaproic acid is the antidote used to reverse bleeding complications caused by fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase.
